results.title: Curious George
results.brief_description: The mischievous exploits of Curious George the monkey in a delightful puppet animation adapted from the book of the same title by H.A. Rey. George is brought from the wilds of the jungle to the sophistication of the city and experiences a few mishaps along the way.

results.title: Cup final [1961]
results.brief_description: Sporting documentary on the 1961 FA Cup final of Tottenham Hotspurs versus Leicester City at Wembley Stadium. Historical in the sense that Spurs won 2-0 and became the first team in the history of English football to win both the League and Cup double.
results.description: Sporting documentary on the 1961 FA Cup final of Tottenham Hotspurs versus Leicester City at Wembley Stadium. Historical in the sense that Spurs won 2-0 and became the first team in the history of English football to win both the League and Cup double.

results.title: Culture, time & place
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, DLGHS and GPN
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Language, schooling and the interactions of everyday life are vehicles of acculturation that communicate values, beliefs, attitudes and expectations to children. Observing a traditional Japanese religious festival, we explore the myth and ritual which help children see their relationship to time, place and values.

results.title: Culture change
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Faces of culture”.
The most important aspect of any culture is the ability to adapt and change. Change can be revolution, change may walk quietly and speak softly, change may come from inside a culture through a leader of vision. The sources of change may be technological, environmental or ideological. This program looks at good and bad aspects of change, in particular at the cargo cults of New Guinea, colonial India and the jungles of Brazil. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Culture as nature
results.creator_credit: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC, RM Productions and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
Fifty years ago our culture became that of the mass media, crammed with stimuli, an overload of advertising and technology. The late 19th century saw the arrival of industrial imagery; then it was the sign and print which dominated. In this fight between painting and media, art could not win. Pop sensibility’s good side was letting art react to mass culture; its bad side was the manipulation of promotional garbage. Yet even in today’s culture, man is judgemental - choice and taste may yet preserve the responsibility of painting. Written and narrated by Robert Hughes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Richardson, Lorna Pegram, BBC, RM Productions and Time-Life Films

results.title: Culture and personality
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Coast Community College District and Holt, Rinehart and Winston
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Faces of culture”.
This program sets out to uncover the links between culture and personality, to know the dancer from the dance. We are shaped and moulded by the core values of the culture we live in, whether subtly, by absorbing all that surrounds us or directly, by teaching, example and indoctrination. The program looks at the early work of Margaret Mead in Samoa and New Guinea, at Ruth Benedict’s study of the Japanese and Eriksen’s studies of German aggression. Other cultures’ core values - kinship in China, rugged individualism in the U.S. are discussed as well as the dangers inherent in reducing human personality to racial stereotypes. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Cultural heritage
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems of World Order”.
Tourism is now a giant worldwide industry providing an important source of revenue. This film shows how much of the heritage that we flock to see is being destroyed by tourism, modern technology and pollution. Discusses who should bear the cost and responsibility of this, using examples.

group_siblings.title: Communication satellites

results.title: Cultural conflict
results.creator_credit: David Zweck and Country Education Project
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English for H.S.C. students”.
A program of interviews and discussions led by Peter Couchman. The texts “Mister Johnson” (Joyce Carey), “The Inheritors” (William Golding), “A Place Apart” (Dervla Murphy) and “The Immigrants” (Wendy Lowenstein and Morag Loh) are considered in examining the causes of cultural conflict, how people are affected by it, how conflict can both enrich and impoverish individuals and communities and how conflict is resolved. Also appearing are Dr. M. McLaughlin and Charles D’Aprano.
results.description:
Episode of Series “English for H.S.C. students”.
A program of interviews and discussions led by Peter Couchman. The texts “Mister Johnson” (Joyce Carey), “The Inheritors” (William Golding), “A Place Apart” (Dervla Murphy) and “The Immigrants” (Wendy Lowenstein and Morag Loh) are considered in examining the causes of cultural conflict, how people are affected by it, how conflict can both enrich and impoverish individuals and communities and how conflict is resolved. Also appearing are Dr. M. McLaughlin and Charles D’Aprano.

results.title: Cults: choice or coercion
results.brief_description: Explores the legal, moral and emotional questions raised by contemporary cults. A young man who was indoctrinated into the Unification Church (Moonies) explains inside workings of the cult, and their parents give an account of the intervention and “deprogramming” of their son. Supplemented by interviews with Dr. Margaret Singer, who has done extensive research on cults and mind control.
